justification: The authors state: “Two of these measures assessed aspects of individual thinking styles. These were a 12-item Need for Cognition Scale (NFC; Cacioppo & Petty, 1982) to capture individual differences in tendency to engage in elaborative thinking.”
The paper notes that participants completed “a 7-item Cognitive Reflective Task (CRT …) to capture individual differences in reliance on analytical (vs. intuitive) thinking.”

measured_by: adapted Inclusion of Others in the Self Scale
justification: Under Additional Measures the authors describe “an adapted Inclusion of Others in the Self Scale … where participants select one of seven pairs of circles … that best describes their relationship with Americans.”

topic_or_construct: Perceived similarity to the typical American
justification: They further state: “We also asked participants to answer the question, ‘How similar do you think you are to the typical American?’ with responses made on a seven-point unnumbered scale.”

measured_by: unnumbered 10-point scale asking ‘How many Americans would believe this claim?’
justification: For Experiment 1 the consensus measure is described: “participants were asked ‘How many Americans do you think would believe this claim?’, and made their responses on an unnumbered ten-point scale with the endpoints ‘hardly anyone’ … and ‘almost everyone.’”

measured_by: unnumbered 10-point scale asking ‘How many Americans know this information?’
justification: In Experiment 2 the authors explain: “participants were asked ‘How many Americans know this information?’, and made their responses on an unnumbered ten-point scale with the endpoints ‘hardly anyone’ … and ‘almost everyone.’”
